task.task_description: This is a multi-physics detector design and optimization task that combines geometric design exploration with Monte Carlo simulation validation. The user needs to design a silicon pixel tracking detector by systematically exploring different detector topologies (planar layers, cylindrical barrel, forward disks) and optimizing geometric parameters (layer spacing, silicon thickness) to achieve optimal momentum resolution while minimizing material budget. The task requires using Geant4 simulations to validate designs by tracking muons at multiple energy points and evaluating key performance metrics including energy deposition, hit detection efficiency, and material budget contribution. This is specifically a detector physics engineering task that balances theoretical design principles with computational validation.
task.goal: Design and optimize a silicon pixel tracking detector that achieves good momentum resolution for charged particles in the 1-50 GeV/c range while minimizing material budget

constraints.description: Must minimize material budget while maintaining hit detection
Must test up to 4 different configurations
Must explore both topology AND parameters
Energy deposit should be approximately 0.1 MeV for MIP in 300 μm Si
Must use mu- particles in Geant4 particle gun

task.context:
Design a silicon pixel tracking detector for measuring charged particle momenta in the 1-50 GeV/c range.

The tracker must achieve good momentum resolution while minimizing material budget.

**GEOMETRY EXPLORATION:**
Consider different detector topologies:
- Planar layers (flat silicon wafers in a stack)
- Cylindrical barrel (silicon layers wrapped around beam axis - common in collider experiments)
- Forward disks (perpendicular to beam for forward tracking)

The geometry tool supports multiple modes:
- sampling_calorimeter: layered structures (can use topology="box" or topology="cylinder_barrel")
- custom_spec: full flexibility with solids, volumes, placements
- raw_gdml: complete control via GDML

Starting point: 4 silicon layers with 300 μm thickness each, 5 cm spacing.

Optimize the detector geometry (topology, layer spacing, silicon thickness) to minimize multiple scattering while maintaining hit detection.

Use Geant4 to simulate muon tracks at various momenta (1, 5, 10, 50 GeV/c) and evaluate:
1. Energy deposit per layer (should be ~0.1 MeV for MIP in 300 μm Si)
2. Hit detection efficiency
3. Material budget contribution

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Use mu- particles in Geant4 particle gun at the specified momenta
- Silicon (G4_Si) has X₀ = 9.37 cm, so 300 μm = 0.032 X₀ per layer
- Test up to 4 configurations exploring both topology AND parameters
- Consider: How does cylindrical vs planar geometry affect track reconstruction?

steps.name: define_detector_requirements
steps.description: Define the silicon pixel detector design problem including momentum range requirements, material budget constraints, and performance metrics

steps.name: explore_geometry_concepts
steps.description: Analyze the physics implications of different detector topologies (planar, cylindrical barrel, forward disks) for momentum resolution and material budget optimization

steps.name: generate_baseline_planar_geometry
steps.description: Generate GDML geometry file for baseline planar silicon detector with 4 layers, 300 μm thickness, 5 cm spacing

steps.name: simulate_baseline_planar
steps.description: Run Geant4 simulation of muons at multiple momenta (1, 5, 10, 50 GeV/c) through baseline planar detector

steps.name: analyze_baseline_performance
steps.description: Analyze baseline planar detector simulation results to extract energy deposits, hit efficiency, and material budget metrics

steps.name: plot_baseline_results
steps.description: Create publication-quality plots of baseline detector performance including energy deposit histograms, efficiency vs momentum, and material budget visualization

steps.name: generate_cylindrical_barrel_geometry
steps.description: Generate GDML geometry file for cylindrical barrel silicon detector with 4 cylindrical layers at increasing radii

steps.name: simulate_cylindrical_barrel
steps.description: Run Geant4 simulation of muons at multiple momenta through cylindrical barrel detector

steps.name: analyze_cylindrical_performance
steps.description: Analyze cylindrical barrel detector simulation results and compare with baseline planar performance

steps.name: generate_optimized_thickness_geometry
steps.description: Generate GDML geometry file for optimized detector with reduced silicon thickness (200 μm) to minimize material budget while maintaining detection efficiency

steps.name: simulate_optimized_thickness
steps.description: Run Geant4 simulation of muons through thickness-optimized detector to evaluate material budget vs efficiency trade-off

steps.name: analyze_thickness_optimization
steps.description: Analyze thickness-optimized detector performance and quantify material budget reduction vs detection efficiency trade-off

steps.name: generate_optimized_spacing_geometry
steps.description: Generate GDML geometry file for spacing-optimized detector with increased layer separation (7 cm) to improve momentum resolution through increased lever arm

steps.name: simulate_optimized_spacing
steps.description: Run Geant4 simulation of muons through spacing-optimized detector to evaluate momentum resolution improvement

steps.name: analyze_final_optimization
steps.description: Analyze final optimized detector performance and compare all four configurations across all performance metrics

steps.name: create_performance_comparison_plots
steps.description: Generate comprehensive comparison plots showing energy deposits, detection efficiency, and material budget for all four detector configurations with error bars

steps.name: evaluate_optimization_success
steps.description: Assess whether the detector optimization has successfully achieved the goal of good momentum resolution in 1-50 GeV/c range while minimizing material budget

steps.name: generate_detector_design_report
steps.description: Synthesize all simulation results and analysis into comprehensive detector design report with recommendations for optimal silicon pixel tracker configuration

plan.reasoning: This workflow systematically explores silicon pixel detector design by testing four different configurations that explore both topology (planar vs cylindrical) and parameters (thickness and spacing). It starts with a baseline planar detector, progresses to cylindrical barrel geometry for better angular coverage, then optimizes thickness to minimize material budget and spacing to improve momentum resolution. Each configuration is simulated with muons across the full momentum range (1-50 GeV/c) and analyzed for energy deposits, detection efficiency, and material budget. The workflow includes mandatory visualization steps after each analysis and concludes with comprehensive performance comparison and design recommendations. The approach balances theoretical detector physics principles with computational validation through Geant4 simulations.
